title: Chief Finance & Operating Officer – AG Barr

core.role: Stewards AG Barr’s financial strategy and group operations, balancing disciplined capital allocation with supply-chain execution to deliver the 5-15-20 growth model commitments:contentReference[oaicite:0]{index=0}:contentReference[oaicite:2]{index=2}.
core.userGoalStatement: Sustain double-digit returns while funding brand-led growth, integrating acquisitions, and meeting science-based sustainability targets.
core.coreBelief: Predictable cash generation and credible ESG delivery are essential to protect shareholder confidence.
core.contentImplication: Frame DHL outcomes in balance-sheet, cash-flow, and risk terms rather than generic efficiency language.

items.Description: Hit revenue, operating margin, and ROCE benchmarks set by the 5-15-20 model while maintaining a net cash position:contentReference[oaicite:1]{index=1}:contentReference[oaicite:2]{index=2}.
Deploy capital into growth, infrastructure, and M&A with disciplined payback expectations and minimal balance-sheet strain:contentReference[oaicite:1]{index=1}.
Oversee end-to-end operational performance so manufacturing, logistics, and customer service deliver contracted SLAs and productivity gains.
Provide accurate forecasts, protect dividend growth, and articulate investment case narratives to analysts and shareholders:contentReference[oaicite:2]{index=2}.
Embed SBTi-approved carbon targets and packaging compliance (DRS/EPR) within operational plans to de-risk regulatory exposure:contentReference[oaicite:1]{index=1}.

responsibilities.contentImplication: All proposals must resemble board-ready business cases with quantified ROI, cash timing, and ESG assurances.

items: Corporate finance, treasury, and covenant management
Capital markets communications and investor relations
ESG reporting frameworks and science-based targets
Enterprise risk mitigation and regulatory compliance
knowledge.contentImplication: Use CFO language — ROCE uplift, free-cash-flow conversion, payback periods, and downside sensitivity — to build credibility.

items.Description: DHL-funded warehousing and transport infrastructure reduces AG Barr’s upfront capex load while accelerating Project Gold timelines.
End-to-end data integration and open-book reporting give the CFO forecast accuracy for guidance, board packs, and lender confidence.
Low-carbon fleet, net-zero facilities, and Scope 3 tracking tools evidence progress toward SBTi milestones:contentReference[oaicite:1]{index=1}.

connectionOpportunities.contentImplication: Anchor conversations in quantified financial returns, risk transfer, and measurable ESG contributions.

items: Protect ROCE above 20% and operating margins around 15%:contentReference[oaicite:1]{index=1}:contentReference[oaicite:2]{index=2}
Maintain positive net cash and dividend progression while funding growth:contentReference[oaicite:1]{index=1}
Demonstrate credible Scope 3 carbon reductions aligned to 2030 and 2050 goals:contentReference[oaicite:1]{index=1}
Derisk large-scale investments and integrations (Boost, Funkin, MOMA) without operational disruption
motivations.contentImplication: Show precisely how DHL programmes underpin board KPIs and shareholder guidance.

items.Description: Partnership models that shift warehouse and fleet investment off balance sheet while preserving control and optionality:contentReference[oaicite:2]{index=2}.
Scenario-ready data, KPIs, and governance that support market briefings and sustain the investment case narrative:contentReference[oaicite:2]{index=2}.
Traceable carbon, packaging, and ethical sourcing performance that evidences SBTi-aligned progress and DRS/EPR readiness:contentReference[oaicite:1]{index=1}.

needs.contentImplication: Translate DHL capabilities into measurable balance-sheet relief, investor-grade reporting, and risk mitigation.

items.Description: Concern that logistics partners will require significant upfront commitments, eroding free cash flow and dividend cover.
Switching from an incumbent 3PL could jeopardise SLA delivery, raising the risk of retailer penalties and reputational damage.
Scepticism toward unverified carbon claims that cannot be audited for Scope 3 reporting.

perceptionGaps.contentImplication: Provide audited case studies, contractual risk-sharing mechanisms, and transparent investment structures.

items: Competing capital priorities between brand investment, M&A, and infrastructure upgrades
Inflationary cost pressure on packaging, energy, and logistics squeezing operating margin
Fragmented data flows from current partners hindering consolidated financial reporting
frustrations.contentImplication: Position DHL as the partner consolidating spend, stabilising costs, and simplifying governance.

items.Emotional_Response: Heightened anxiety about credibility with analysts and the Board
items.Messaging_Implication: Lead with stress-tested scenarios, contractual guarantees, and governance cadence.

items.Trigger: Board scrutiny of net-zero progress and regulatory readiness
items.Emotional_Response: Desire for fast, verifiable ESG proof points
items.Messaging_Implication: Show metric-backed carbon reduction, DRS/EPR compliance plans, and third-party validation.

items.Trigger: Large upfront investment requests from partners
items.Emotional_Response: Scepticism about capital efficiency and payback
items.Messaging_Implication: Present pay-as-you-grow commercial models, shared risk, and balance-sheet neutral options.

emotionalTriggers.contentImplication: Use reassurance and evidence-based storytelling backed by numbers, not assertions.

engagementApproach.description: Finance-first operator who expects investor-grade detail, scenario planning, and cross-functional governance clarity.

items: Analytical, data-driven, and intolerant of marketing spin
Evaluates partners through risk-adjusted returns and covenant impact
Seeks peer validation and external benchmarks before committing
behaviors.contentImplication: Provide concise, metrics-rich briefings with clear next steps and executive alignment.

problemSolvingMethod.description: Runs sensitivity analyses and board-level risk assessments before endorsing change.
problemSolvingMethod.value: Prefers scenario modelling with clear triggers, mitigations, and financial dashboards.

items: Engages best with CFO-to-CFO and COO-to-COO dialogue backed by solution architects
Wants structured governance with defined escalation paths and accountability matrices
Expects diligence packs, references, and site evidence before advancing
collaborationInsights.contentImplication: Prepare multi-disciplinary teams and documentation at every stage gate.

items.Description: “Balance-sheet shock absorber” — partner takes the capital hit so AG Barr can stay agile.
“No surprises dashboard” — continuous visibility prevents earnings shocks.

analogies.contentImplication: Use metaphors that tie logistics decisions directly to financial predictability.

messagingAngles.description: Emphasise financially validated, risk-mitigated growth pathways.
